ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Major theories in physics. How to do close analysis of film. How to make abstract connections between two seemingly unrelated fields.
None, I didn't learn any new film knowledge or physics knowledge.
I learnt about the connection of physics to cinema
Theoretical comparisons between physics and cinema
film analysis, relating cinema and physics

A nice, intuitive, very high-level overview of some important topics in physics from one of the world's leading experimental physicists, accompanied by a (mostly not very related) discussion of film history by a wonderfully charismatic film studies professor.
I developed an ability to think about art and science in relation to one another.
I learned so much about film and media, and even though i knew many of the physics topics, i truly learned how physics relates and intersects with film and cinematography
I learned about many interesting facets of cinema and physics and how the two fields interact and intersect.
I learned about the evolution of modern cinema and its intersection with concepts in physics!
This course was an experiment in combining two drastically different topics, the world of physics and cinema.
Learned a lot about shot techniques in cinema and quantum mechanics! Learned how to think creatively in connecting the two different disciplines.
Philosophical intersections and oppositions between cinema and physics.

This was an incredible class. I learned so much about film and physics and think about both in an entirely new way. Physics is a very helpful lens to learn about the advent of different film techniques and technologies, and vice versa, cinema is a great way to understand otherwise complex physics ideas.
A juxtaposition of how modern day cinema and physics talk to each other on various notions, such as space, time, information, etc.
I learned a lot about cinema and looking at a movie more perceptively.

I learned how to view both cinema and physics as tools to better understand the world  and they can reinforce and augment each other.  Having never taken a film class before, I definitely improved my ability to analyze and understand film techniques, and I learned some basic film history.  I had a more solid science background (AP Chem and Physics in high school), so the physics material was less new, though I learned a lot more about quantum mechanics, which was exciting.

The most meaningful insight was how to put cinema and physics in dialogue with each other, something I never would have thought to do without this class.
This is a great course for non-STEM people. Fun to learn about physics from a humanities perspective. Great course for even those who don't know much about film as well.
The ways in which physics and film studies can be linked together. Basically a conversation between two experts in their respective fields.
I learned about how frontier concepts in 20th and 21st-century physics were similarly explored in the medium of cinema, and the "poetic" resonances between the two disciplines.
I learned about the intersectional similarities in approaches to both film and physics.
I started to see a new way to think about physics. It was such a treat to see a lifelong physicist interacting and engaging with cinema, another subject area I love so much.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course are that it allows students to freely explore both the fields of physics and cinema through loose thematic links. The weaknesses are that it doesn't allow for deep or focused knowledge in either field.

They tried to make it work but the way the class was structured and taught was not conducive to any sort of learning. The connections between physics and film made no sense. From the physics side, how the topics were discussed via film didn't make physical sense. From the film side, physics didn't need to be brought in to teach about film, it just made things confusing. I knew it wasn't a class about physics in film before I took it, but I think that would have been a much more solid base to teach from and could actually be a good learning opportunity.

it was engaging 
could be more interactive and incorporate breakout rooms

I really liked the interdisciplinary approach that the professors had. I hope Yale continues to offer more similar classes! I think some of the lectures would have benefitted from a clearer structure, but overall it was an eye opening look at both fields.
two great professors in their own right. interesting take on an interdisciplinary course. felt a bit all over the place, though.

This course was heavily structured, which was a strength; one could easily imagine an attempted combination like this falling apart. The topics in physics and cinema didn't always seem to cohere, though.
This course is really great for inspiring intersectional and cross-medium thinking for students. However, the physics lectures could be made more approachable for non-physics students

there are really no weaknesses, the course is taught in a dual professor way which was really cool because every topic had multiple perspectives and provided a lot of insight. the final project was also super fun

The teaching was good and there was lots of TA support, but it was not able to bring out a lot of student engagement. I think the causes of this, however, were mostly because of the Zoom format where people could turn off their cameras.

I think the big strength is that you have Devoret and Casetti, who are heavyweights in their departments, orchestrating a dialogue together. The big downside is that I think that they're sometimes more interested in the ties between the subject than making sure the students get what they're talking about
The strengths of this course are the professors' passion for their subjects. It was so great to learn from them about things they care deeply about.
The course did not seem to be fully figured out, and several times I felt as though the lectures were just a combination of two disjoint ideas.
Loved the professors and their enthusiasm about the material.

I loved the structure of this course. It allowed for so much freedom in terms of completing the work, which was very helpful for a stressful virtual semester. There were very few, large assignments (as opposed to many small ones) which was great because you could organize doing the work in a way that is beneficial to you. It's the kind of class where you get what you put into it - which, and I emphasize - is ESSENTIAL for such an innovative course. The thing is, some students were very good at physics and some very good at film, and some familiar with neither. This is why the flexibility with the major assignments and the lack of emphasis on remembering gritty, irrelevant details was great. It allowed for much more lateral thinking about the subjects and I felt I came away with a deep appreciation for each topic.

Strengths: the professors. I don't think you could have another more interesting pair of distinguished scholars.

Weaknesses: limited in-class discussion. Most of the interaction took place via discussion posts - more of a COVID restriction than course design.
I wish there were viewing times for the required films so you could watch it and discuss with the ta or other classmates afterwards.
Lecture did not seem organized and assignments also not great.

Professors Casetti and Devoret are a great duo.  Sometimes the lectures could feel a bit disorganized or like the connections between the two subjects were being a bit forced, but I always had a great time listening to them talk.  I think the course could be improved by interweaving more of each discipline throughout rather than splitting the semester in two to focus mainly on film in the first half and mainly on physics in the second.
Connected thematically. I felt like readings could have been clearer and there could have been more discussion of film techniques and how to evaluate films.
Not enough interactive components to the class. Maybe a section?
I thought the course was very interesting in its approach to a cross-disciplinary investigation! I think it could be improved by having some variations on the lecture format each week.
This course was quite engaging and enjoyable. Im sure itll be even better in person!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There could've been more room for discussion between students. The strengths were that the TA's were very attentive and gave wonderful feedback. Carolyn Jacobs also hosted sessions to learn how to do close analysis of film which was helpful.
No reason to make lecture live and tell us we have to show up. We weren't allowed to talk or ask questions during lecture so it should have been asynchronous.
success
It was nice that classes were recorded
i thought the TFs did a great job in aiding the professors in showing the films in class. perhaps more improvement on the structure and organization.
Zoom lectures were a reasonable format for this course, though there was no real reason for attendance to be mandatory; there was never any participation.
The discussion response feature was a successful way to encourage student engagement with course material.
all practices succeddes
As mentioned in the above question, I think student engagement would have been helped if students had been encouraged or required to keep cameras on.
All things considered, I think the course was designed as successfully as possible. I liked our lectures and appreciated the discussion posts!
The engagement from the class was relatively low compared to my other experiences this semester, and there was little to no feedback at any point.
So glad they recorded the lectures. No weaknesses.
I think the weekly responses on Canvas were good, but I would have appreciated more of a real-time discussion of the material covered in class instead

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you want to understand many different and large concepts in physics while also watching some cool movies, this is a good course.

No, never. It's not at all what you expect. You'll find yourself staring at weird videos with shrill noises and contemplating if a cut between two people talking in a conversation is time travel. I. Not a film major, but from what I saw from the film side of this class, I never want to take another film class. It's a complete waste of time.
yes - good science credit and interesting content
Yes, I would recommend it to both humanities and STEM students. I think there is a lot to offer both fields.

for those interested in understanding the connections between cinema and physics on a base level, definitely. although it was a bit disorganized of an approach so for those that appreciate more structure in a course, I'd look towards other ones.
I'm not sure I'd recommend this course. Maybe for someone's senior spring.
Yes - I think this is a wonderful way to think outside your comfort zone as both a stem or humanities student.
I would most definitely recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn about cinema and physics because its the coolest topic wver
I think I would recommend it. It was not too difficult and the subject matter on the whole was interesting.
Good QR credit if that's what you were looking for, but it was a wild time.
Yes for sure, it was a great way to explore the intersection of STEM and humanities.
It was an interesting idea that I think needs further development to be a class again.
Definitely. Anyone looking to get a glimpse into either cinema or physics would really enjoy this class!
Absolutely.

Yes. I think this is one of the very "classic" Yale courses where you gain brand new insights through interdisciplinary perspectives. The two professors are absolute gems. As a stats major, I thoroughly enjoyed the class, especially the interactions between two professors, two subjects, and two ways of perceiving the world we live in and beyond.
No
Yes I would definitely recommend! Professors Devoret and Cassettis love for their subjects is very clear and their dialogue is extremely interesting!!
Yes, it is a fascinating once in a lifetime class. Devoret and Cassetti are both extremely knowledgeable in their fields which makes for excellent discourse.
A very interesting synthesis of two disciplines--you'll watch great movies and learn some interesting physics concepts!
This course is a lot of fun for anyone with an interest in either film or quantum physics who is looking to expand their knowledge about a new topic.
Absolutely. This course was fun and manageable, and I learned quite a bit about topics I likely wouldnt have been exposed to without it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: sometimes recorded lecture
N/A
Na
N/A
N/A
All lecture
The lectures were recorded for students who could not attend the live lectures. Other than that we watched films and completed readings.
Office hours were available once a week with the TA. There were also discussion board posts to engage with lecture material.
